posts.name: AlexG
posts.cooked:
The text is:

Before I get into this I want to say that I am not a machinist, and I studied economics in college, so this is all very vibes based. My team is hoping to make use of snap rings this year, particularly for the gearboxes on our elevator(s). They have already designed one that way so I want to try and make it work… We have no lathe and myself and multiple other mentors have tried to find someone to do it for us with no success. We do however, have a Tormach PCNC 1100 and there is a Tormach 24R at my office that I can use.

I was thinking that we could machine soft jaws that can hold 3/8" and 1/2" hex shafts in a vertical position, clamp that in our vise, and cut the snap ring grooves with an appropriately sized slitting saw, probably on the 1100 to get a low enough spindle speed. I am aware this will only work for a sufficiently short shaft.

I am trying to think about why this would not work before I buy the tooling, and I just can’t see why it wouldn’t, but as I said I have absolutely zero real education on these matters so I was hoping I may be able to get some insight. Thanks.

**Cleaned Version:** Before getting started, I want to clarify that I’m not a machinist; I majored in economics instead. This entire project feels more like a creative endeavor than a precise engineering task. Our team plans to utilize snap rings this year, specifically for the gearboxes on our elevators. They’ve already designed a system that works, so we’re aiming to adapt it… Unfortunately, we don’t have access to a lathe, and neither I nor several other mentors have been able to secure someone who can perform the necessary operations. However, we do possess a Tormach PCNC 1100 and a Tormach 24R, both of which we can use to our advantage. We’re considering creating soft jaws capable of holding 3/8"- and 1/2"-diameter hex shafts in a vertical position, clamping them in place within our shop’s vice. The plan is to use an appropriately sized slitting saw to cut the snap ring grooves. Given the capabilities of the Tormach 1100, we aim to achieve a sufficiently low spindle speed for this operation. One concern is that this method might only be viable for relatively short shafts, given its limitations. At this stage, we haven’t identified any clear reasons why this approach wouldn’t work, though our lack of formal machining training leaves us uncertain. We’d appreciate any insights or advice you might be able to provide. Thank you.

posts.name: Ada T
posts.cooked: With a miter saw, being meticulous about it, makes me wonder if a slitting saw would suffice (not a professional machinist or engineer).

posts.name: Patrick
posts.cooked: We have abused sliding saws for weird tasks that should have been done on a lathe. In our case, it was a rather thick saw used for undercutting wheel flanges, but I think it would work on snap ring grooves. Snap ring grooves are difficult to machine, so we use super low profile shaft end bolts and spacers.

posts.name: AlexG
posts.cooked: Thank you for this information. There is not currently a packaging limitation which requires snap rings. We just want to finally make use of them, and I think this is a good opportunity for everyone involved to learn more about machining. We haven't done something on the machine for the first time in a few years now. Maybe this should have been worked out earlier, but if we need to do anything other than adjusting feeds and speeds, we will go back to tapping the shafts and work it out after the build season.

posts.name: Ada T
posts.cooked: I clamped it down and rotated it 6 times, bringing the miter down a tiny bit each time until the handle hit a piece of wood

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked: You know… there’s a different way to do this in a mill. Obtain: One snap-ring cutter for lathe, or equivalent. One collet that is the right size to fit your shaft. Stick shaft into collet into mill head. Set up snap-ring cutter in vise of mill. Align cutter near-center on shaft and at proper place. Fire up mill at typical lathe speed and very carefully feed snap-ring cutter into shaft until you get to the right depth. Obviously this is a “be cautious” move, but the basic idea is to spin the shaft and align the cutter.

A “snap ring cutter” on a lathe is a grooving tool, and the closest equivalent on a mill is a slitting saw, which should not be spun at lathe speeds due to their low SFM and feed requirements, necessitating a rotary table or CNC control. Another option involves using a thin grooving insert on a boring head, though this approach can lead to stiffness issues when attempting to cut a long cantilevered workpiece with a long tool during discontinuous cuts. As such, this method is not recommended.

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked: Alex_Y: A 'snap ring cutter' on a lathe is a grooving tool. I’d use that because you’re already spinning the PART, and the slitting saw isn’t designed for single-tooth cutting.

posts.name: SndMndBdy
posts.cooked: My hunch is that the OP’s approach will work. One potential issue is that you might not find a slitting saw that matches the size of the snap ring groove you're aiming to create. A helpful tip is to purchase a cutting tool that's slightly smaller than the slot you're trying to make. Once you've done that, design your slot so that the extra portion extends into whatever you're attempting to retain, such as bearing surfaces or gears. This method should function well as long as the extra part isn’t excessively thick—it should prevent weakening the shaft or reducing the contact area with the bearing.

posts.name: Phil Szymanowski
posts.cooked:
This is what I have typically done in a pinch if a lathe was taken up. It gets slightly more complicated with hex shafts, but nowadays with 3D printers, making a collet adapter for a hex shaft becomes very easy.  
They also sell 1/2-inch hex collets for fairly cheap.  
At one place I worked, they had this grooving tool permanently mounted to the mill table, allowing easy creation of a groove.

link_counts.title: HHIP 3900-1528 5C Precision Hex Collet, 1/2": Amazon.com: Tools & Home Improvement

posts.name: Mark Collins
posts.cooked: Mount the material in the spindle and the lathe tooling in the vise. Instant lathe.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: If you want to set up a shaft with excellent positional accuracy, consider using a slitting saw that’s specifically designed for precise cutting. Smaller diameter slitting saws, such as 1-inch OD models, are ideal for this task. To achieve the desired groove dimensions, you may need to make multiple passes—either cutting twice to reach the required groove width or stacking two saws for precision. Additionally, refer to the product specifications for acceptable groove width tolerances.

posts.name: Chris Herzog
posts.cooked:
The user is discussing the use of a snap-ring cutter on a milling machine instead of a lathe. They suggest using a collet in the mill and positioning the cutter near-center on the shaft before carefully feeding it in. However, this method introduces complications due to the mill's design, which is not optimized for turning operations. Using a collet in a mill may lead to inaccuracies or vibrations since mills primarily use chucks or spindle supports. Additionally, relying on snap rings requires precise alignment to avoid binding or stripping the cutter, adding unnecessary risk.

An alternative suggestion is using a screw and washer setup, which is simpler, provides a positive grip, and avoids the need for precise alignment, making it more beginner-friendly. While the process described could work similarly on a lathe, switching to a mill adds unnecessary complexity. A screw and washer method ensures smoother learning without the associated risks, promoting better outcomes for beginners.

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked: This is what I have typically done in a pinch if a lathe was taken up. Gets slightly more complicated with hex shaft, but nowadays with 3D printers you can make a collet adapter for a hex shaft very easily. They also sell 1/2" hex collets for fairly cheap. It’s worth noting that the Tormach PCNC 1100 uses a R8-style collets, which are a bit more expensive. When we bought our mill we got a few Drill Chuck collets with it, and I think if it was me I would try to make one of those work first. I think the biggest limitation to using a mill for this kind of thing would be the length of the stock you’re trying to groove, since mill collets usually are somewhat depth-limited and you don’t want long stock spinning unsupported out the end of a spindle. Woops, got me too. Darn necro posts.

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked: Ground down a tool steel lathe parting tool to the width needed for snap rings we typically use. Depth control remains difficult because we lack sufficient calipers for the grove. Likely, this task exceeds my abilities without help from highly skilled students.

posts.name: Gus Michel II
posts.cooked:
Depth controls remain challenging because we lack sufficient-thin calipers to fit in the grove. To address this issue, I propose creating a sheet metal jig made from material no thicker than your snap rings. Here's an illustration similar to what I designed:

![diameterJig](https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/4X/4/3/c/43c78b9ed82ca1cc449b871ae2edf64298ebb973.png)

This jig aims to drop entirely into the groove when the correct diameter is achieved. Until then, observing where the jig pauses offers insight into how much further to cut—practicing and calibrating along the way. A single jig may suffice if used for consistent or recurring sizes. Additionally, adjusting the taper angle beyond necessity was unnecessary, as demonstrated in LibreOffice Impress.

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked: What an excellent idea!

posts.name: Gus Michel II
posts.cooked:
Thinking about a better geometry for the jig... The first idea is to cut the notch on the shorter side, making the notch longer. This design resembles a sheet metal piece attached to the end of a barbecue fork.

For a round shaft, select the parallel sides such that their length equals the desired depth of the cut. This ensures the distance from the shaft's edge to the jig's opening matches proportionally without any offset. However, for polygonal shafts, like a hexagon, align the jig with one side when measuring since the angle affects the calculation.

Next, choose the taper angle so that the remaining depth to cut is a simple fraction—either 1/8 or 1/10—of the space between the end of the aligned shaft and the notch's end. I'm unsure whether this involves trigonometric functions like arctangent or arcsine at this stage of the morning.
